childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1986-1998

You were born the year the Space Shuttle Challenger exploded 73 seconds after launch, killing seven crew members including teacher Christa McAuliffe. The whole country watched. Your parents probably remember exactly where they were. You don't remember it at all, but it shaped the world you grew up in—one where technology could fail spectacularly, publicly, catastrophically.

Three months later, Chernobyl's reactor melted down in Ukraine, spreading radioactive fallout across Europe. Two disasters that shattered faith in the institutions supposed to keep people safe. Welcome to life.

Your childhood was the end of the Cold War and the beginning of whatever came next. You were three when the Berlin Wall fell. Five when the Soviet Union collapsed. The existential threat your parents lived under just... vanished. They didn't quite know what to do with that relief, and neither did the country.

You grew up in the golden age of Saturday morning cartoons, Nintendo, and the mall as social center. You probably had a landline with a cord you stretched as far as it would go for privacy. You learned to ride a bike, rollerblade, and make prank calls from pay phones. If your parents wanted to find you, they yelled your name until you came home.

You were eleven when Princess Diana died, twelve during the Monica Lewinsky scandal, thirteen at Columbine, fifteen on 9/11. Your childhood ended gradually, then suddenly, in a September morning that divided everything into before and after.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Millennials

You're an early Millennial, sometimes called an 'elder Millennial' or 'geriatric Millennial' by people who think they're being funny. Born in 1986, you're squarely in the 1981-1996 cohort that Pew Research codified as the official definition. There are roughly 72 million of you in the US.

You're old enough to remember the before times—before the internet was ubiquitous, before smartphones, before social media became everyone's second brain. You learned cursive. You used card catalogs. You know what it was like to be genuinely unreachable.

The defining generational moment was 9/11. You were fifteen. Sophomore year of high school. Old enough to understand the implications, young enough for it to fundamentally rewire your worldview. The security state, the forever wars, the ambient anxiety—that's your normal.

You graduated into the 2008 financial crisis, or close enough to feel its devastation. The job market cratered just as you were trying to enter it. The economic promises your parents' generation took for granted—steady employment, home ownership, retirement—turned out to be optional, and the options were off the table.

Your generation gets blamed for killing industries, but you didn't kill anything. You just couldn't afford to keep propping up dying business models while paying off student loans and splitting rent four ways.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

You were born the year Top Gun taught America to feel patriotic about volleyball and fighter jets. Tom Cruise in aviator sunglasses became an archetype. 'Take My Breath Away' played at every school dance for the next decade. Every guy you knew wanted to be Maverick. Some still do.

Ferris Bueller's Day Off came out your birth year—a movie about skipping school and seizing the day that would define an entire generation's fantasy of rebellion. Platoon brought Vietnam back to theaters. The Fly turned Jeff Goldblum into a monster. Stand By Me made nostalgia for childhoods people hadn't finished yet.

Musically, 1986 was peak '80s excess. Whitney Houston dominated with 'Greatest Love of All.' Peter Gabriel released 'Sledgehammer.' Run-DMC collaborated with Aerosmith on 'Walk This Way,' bridging rock and hip-hop in ways that changed everything. The Bangles were walking like Egyptians.

Your childhood was Nickelodeon's golden age—Double Dare, Legends of the Hidden Temple, Are You Afraid of the Dark? You watched Power Rangers and Saved by the Bell. You probably owned a slap bracelet until they got banned for being dangerous. You collected Pogs and forgot why.

Your adolescence belonged to TRL, boy bands versus girl groups, Britney versus Christina. The Matrix came out your senior year of high school. You graduated into a world that suddenly felt like a simulation.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

You were born the year Pixar was founded. The company that would revolutionize animation didn't release Toy Story until you were nine. Microsoft went public in 1986, making Bill Gates one of the richest people alive. The technology that would define your life was being built while you were learning to walk.

Your family probably got their first computer when you were in elementary school. A hulking beige box with a CRT monitor that took up half the desk. You learned to type on it, played Oregon Trail on it, maybe did some homework on it. The internet came later—dial-up that screamed and kicked everyone off the phone.

You were nine when Windows 95 launched and suddenly everyone had a computer. Twelve when Google went online. Fifteen when Wikipedia launched and teachers started warning you not to trust it. Seventeen when MySpace taught you to code HTML for your profile page. Eighteen when Facebook opened to colleges. Twenty-one when the iPhone changed everything.

This makes you a digital bridge generation. You remember life before the internet was omnipresent, but you adopted it early enough to feel native. You can troubleshoot your parents' router and explain TikTok to your grandparents. You're fluent in both worlds.

Your relationship with technology is less codependent than younger generations but more integrated than older ones. You can put your phone down—you just rarely choose to. You remember what boredom felt like before screens filled every gap, and sometimes you miss it.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

January 28, 1986: The Space Shuttle Challenger exploded. Millions of schoolchildren watched live because NASA had promoted the Teacher in Space program. America's faith in technological progress took a hit that day. The future wasn't as inevitable as promised.

April 26, 1986: Chernobyl's Reactor No. 4 melted down in the worst nuclear disaster in history. The Soviet Union tried to cover it up, failed, and the incident became a symbol of everything wrong with that system. The fallout, literal and metaphorical, lasted decades.

You were three when the Berlin Wall fell. Five when the Gulf War played out on CNN like a video game. Seven when the World Trade Center was bombed the first time—a prelude nobody recognized. Ten when Princess Diana died and a billion people watched her funeral.

You were thirteen when Columbine happened. April 20, 1999. The school shooting that created the template. You probably had your first lockdown drill not long after. The phrase 'active shooter' entered the vocabulary of childhood.

You were fifteen on September 11, 2001. High school. You watched the towers fall live on classroom TVs. The wars in Afghanistan and Iraq started and just kept going. By the time you graduated college, they were still happening. By the time you turned thirty, they were still happening.

You were twenty-two when Lehman Brothers collapsed and the economy cratered. Twenty-seven when marriage equality became law. Thirty when Trump won. Thirty-four when COVID shut everything down. Thirty-five when the Capitol was stormed. History keeps accelerating, and you keep being in it.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

If you followed the traditional path—high school, four years of college, straight to work—you graduated in 2008. The year the economy collapsed. The year Lehman Brothers imploded and took the job market with it. Your timing was spectacularly bad through no fault of your own.

Entry-level jobs disappeared. Internships became unpaid or didn't exist. The degree you'd been told was a ticket to the middle class turned out to be a ticket to debt and underemployment. You learned to hustle, to network, to take jobs you were overqualified for because having a job was better than not.

Your generation normalized job-hopping because companies stopped being loyal first. Pensions vanished. Annual raises became 'we're tightening belts' speeches. The implicit contract—work hard, get rewarded—was shredded before you could sign it.

You've worked in offices with exposed brick and foosball tables that promised 'culture' instead of competitive salaries. You've had managers younger than you and executives older who don't understand why you're not grateful for the opportunity. You've watched productivity increase while wages stagnated.

Remote work became standard during COVID, proving you could do your job from anywhere. Now employers expect you to be available everywhere, all the time, from the computer in your bedroom that used to be your escape.

By your late thirties, you've probably found some stability. Or you've reinvented yourself twice. Or you're still figuring it out. All of those are normal for your cohort. None of them match what you were promised.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

You're old enough to remember calling your high school girlfriend's house and talking to her dad first. You passed notes in class. Your first romantic communications were probably via AIM away messages, layered with enough cryptic song lyrics to require interpretation.

Dating apps arrived in your mid-to-late twenties. Tinder launched when you were twenty-six. By then you'd already learned to meet people in person—at parties, through friends, at bars. The app-based approach felt weird at first, then normal, then obligatory, then exhausting.

You've probably had relationships that existed primarily through screens and relationships that predated them. You know both modes. You can evaluate which works better for you. Younger people only know one way.

Your generation delayed marriage longer than any before it. Not because you don't want partnership, but because weddings are expensive, housing is expensive, kids are expensive, and the financial prerequisites kept getting harder to meet. The life script got rewritten mid-chapter.

You communicate in layers—text for logistics, DMs for casual, email for work, calls for emergencies or parents. You know the anxiety of the three dots appearing and disappearing. You've had important conversations happen entirely through a screen and wondered if that counts as having them.

Friendships are maintained across time zones and platforms. Your college friends are scattered. Your work friends change with jobs. The constants are group chats that go quiet for months and then explode over nothing.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

You were fourteen when the dot-com bubble burst. Twenty-two when the 2008 financial crisis obliterated the job market you were about to enter. Thirty-four when COVID collapsed the economy again. You've watched the system fail spectacularly, repeatedly, and you've learned to expect the next collapse.

Student loans are probably a defining feature of your financial life. You were told college was essential, borrowed accordingly, and graduated into an economy that didn't value your degree enough to help you pay it back. The average Millennial carries $38,000 in student debt. Many carry more.

Home ownership—the traditional wealth-building path—has been largely inaccessible. Prices climbed while wages stagnated. Down payments require saving money you don't have while paying rent that keeps increasing. Your parents bought houses with one income. You can barely afford an apartment with two.

You've learned to be resourceful. Side hustles aren't a lifestyle choice—they're survival. You track expenses, optimize savings, and still feel behind. The financial advice written for previous generations doesn't apply. You can't cut back on lattes when you're not buying lattes.

Retirement planning feels like fiction. Social Security might exist when you're 70. It might not. You contribute to a 401(k) if your employer offers one, knowing it won't be enough, doing it anyway because the alternative is worse.

Your financial psychology is defined by scarcity that never quite ends and abundance that never quite arrives. You're playing a game whose rules were written for people with different circumstances, and the best you can do is not lose.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

You've adapted so well to broken systems that you sometimes forget they're broken. Precarity feels normal. Healthcare tied to employment feels normal. Retirement as a fantasy feels normal. You've learned to cope instead of demanding change, and coping can become complicity.

Your generation is so good at self-optimization that you sometimes treat systemic problems like personal failures. Can't afford a house? Must not be saving hard enough. Can't find a good job? Must not be networking hard enough. The hustle culture you grew up in made individual effort the solution to collective problems.

Irony is your default mode, and it protects you from sincerity that might feel dangerous. You can't just like something—you have to qualify it, contextualize it, make it a bit. Earnest enthusiasm feels naive. But irony makes it hard to advocate for yourself without hedging or apologizing.

You're so online that offline action sometimes feels like too much effort. You can mobilize for causes on social media. You can share, retweet, post. But voting rates lag. City council meetings go unattended. The digital activism feels like action, but algorithms don't change policy.

You've also developed a certain superiority about being the bridge generation—old enough to remember the before times, young enough to understand the new. This can make you dismissive of Gen Z's concerns as performative or Boomers' concerns as out of touch. The condescension goes both ways, and it doesn't help.

Your biggest blind spot might be believing you've already seen the worst. You haven't.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s (2006-2016): You entered adulthood right before the economy collapsed. If you went to college, you graduated into the worst job market since the Depression. You took what you could get. You lived with roommates, with parents, with uncertainty. This was supposed to be your exploratory decade. Instead, it was economic survival. You probably changed jobs multiple times, moved cities, started over more than once. By your late twenties, things stabilized slightly, but the scars remained.

Your 30s (2016-2026): You're finishing this decade now. You've probably achieved some stability—a career that makes sense, maybe a partner, possibly kids. Or you've consciously chosen different paths because the traditional ones didn't fit or weren't available. You've watched the world get stranger: pandemic, political chaos, economic whiplash. You've adapted because that's what you do. This decade has been about building something sustainable while everything around you felt temporary.

Your 40s (2026-2036): This will be your peak earning decade, statistically. Your career has either found its groove or you've accepted it won't. Your kids, if you have them, are growing up. Your parents are aging, which brings new responsibilities. You're sandwiched between generations, managing demands from above and below while your own needs wait. This is the decade where you either consolidate what you've built or make one more big change while you still can.

Your 50s (2036-2046): By now you'll have lived through at least five economic crises, multiple pandemics (statistically likely), and the ongoing acceleration of climate change. You'll be thinking about retirement in an era when retirement looks nothing like your parents' version. You'll be the senior voice at work, if you're still working—passing knowledge to people who don't remember what you remember, who can't imagine a world without smartphones. You'll feel old and young at the same time.

Your 60s and beyond (2046+): Retirement might exist. It might be part-time work, gig economy survival, or reliance on family. Social Security's future is uncertain. Climate change will have reshaped where and how people live. The world of your childhood—landlines, video stores, malls, newspapers—will be history. You'll be living history, carrying memories of a world that no longer exists into a world you barely recognize.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

You're part of a birth cohort of roughly 3.8 million people born in 1986. The Millennial generation totals about 72 million in the US—the largest generation until Gen Z catches up.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980), you're more educated, more diverse, more tech-savvy, and significantly poorer. Gen X caught the tail end of affordable housing and stable employment. They got pensions that transitioned to 401(k)s; you just got 401(k)s. They entered the workforce in the '80s and '90s boom. You entered it during the Great Recession.

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964), the wealth gap is almost obscene. Boomers controlled 21% of national wealth at your age. Millennials control 7%. Boomers bought starter homes for a year's salary. You're paying a year's salary in rent. Boomers had one job for life with benefits. You've had five jobs and gig work and still no pension.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012), you're similar in values but different in outlook. You remember optimism. Gen Z grew up in the aftermath of optimism's death. You adapted to smartphones and social media. They were born into them. You still believe systems can be reformed. They're building alternatives because they don't.

Your life expectancy is 78-80 years, slightly lower than previous generations due to 'deaths of despair'—suicide, overdoses, alcoholism. Your generation has higher rates of anxiety, depression, and chronic loneliness than any before. The world you inherited was harder, lonelier, and more expensive than promised.

But you're also more tolerant, more educated, and more committed to equity than previous generations. You've normalized therapy. You've destigmatized mental health. You've pushed for inclusion in ways your parents didn't. The world is more expensive, but it's also, in some ways, more humane. That's at least partly because of you.

year_events: Top Gun dominated the box office
The Oprah Winfrey Show went national
